As a general rinciple, if we would exercise our memories more wisely, we might, in ur very darkest distress, strike a match which would instantaneously indle the lamp of comfort. There is no need for God to create a new hing upon the earth in order to restore believers to joy; if they ould prayerfully rake the ashes of the past, they would find light for he present; and if they would turn to the book of truth and the throne f grace, their candle would soon shine as aforetime. To his conscience the atonement brings eace; to his understanding the gospel brings the richest instruction; o his heart the person of Jesus is the noblest object of affection; to he whole man the truth as it is in Jesus supplies the purest utriment. Thirst is terrible, but Jesus can remove it. Though the soul ere utterly famished, Jesus could restore it.

Proclamation is made most freely, that every thirsty one is welcome. No ther distinction is made but that of thirst. Whether it be the thirst f avarice, ambition, pleasure, knowledge, or rest, he who suffers from t is invited. The thirst may be bad in itself, and be no sign of race, but rather a mark of inordinate sin longing to be gratified with eeper draughts of lust; but it is not goodness in the creature which rings him the invitation, the Lord Jesus sends it freely, and without espect of persons.

Personality is declared most fully. The sinner must come to Jesus, not o works, ordinances, or doctrines, but to a personal Redeemer, who his wn self bare our sins in his own body on the tree. The bleeding, ying, rising Saviour, is the only star of hope to a sinner. Oh for race to come now and drink, ere the sun sets upon the year's last day!

No waiting or preparation is so much as hinted at. Drinking represents reception for which no fitness is required. A fool, a thief, a harlot an drink; and so sinfulness of character is no bar to the invitation o believe in Jesus. We want no golden cup, no bejewelled chalice, in hich to convey the water to the thirsty; the mouth of poverty is elcome to stoop down and quaff the flowing flood. Blistered, leprous, ilthy lips may touch the stream of divine love; they cannot pollute t, but shall themselves be purified. Jesus is the fount of hope. Dear eader, hear the dear Redeemer's loving voice as he cries to each of s,

"IF ANY MAN THIRST,

LET HIM

COME UNTO ME

AND DRINK."

Evening

The harvest is past, the summer is ended, and we are not saved.

Jeremiah 8:20

Not saved! Dear reader, is this your mournful plight? Warned of the udgment to come, bidden to escape for your life, and yet at this oment not saved! You know the way of salvation, you read it in the ible, you hear it from the pulpit, it is explained to you by friends, nd yet you neglect it, and therefore you are not saved. You will be ithout excuse when the Lord shall judge the quick and dead. The Holy pirit has given more or less of blessing upon the word which has been reached in your hearing, and times of refreshing have come from the ivine presence, and yet you are without Christ. All these hopeful easons have come and gone--your summer and your harvest have past--and et you are not saved. Years have followed one another into eternity, nd your last year will soon be here: youth has gone, manhood is going, nd yet you are not saved. Let me ask you--will you ever be saved? Is here any likelihood of it? Already the most propitious seasons have eft you unsaved; will other occasions alter your condition? Means have ailed with you--the best of means, used perseveringly and with the tmost affection--what more can be done for you? Affliction and rosperity have alike failed to impress you; tears and prayers and ermons have been wasted on your barren heart. Are not the robabilities dead against your ever being saved? Is it not more than ikely that you will abide as you are till death forever bars the door f hope? Do you recoil from the supposition? Yet it is a most easonable one: he who is not washed in so many waters will in all robability go filthy to his end. The convenient time never has come, hy should it ever come? It is logical to fear that it never will rrive, and that Felix like, you will find no convenient season till ou are in hell. O bethink you of what that hell is, and of the dread robability that you will soon be cast into it!

Reader, suppose you should die unsaved, your doom no words can picture. rite out your dread estate in tears and blood, talk of it with groans nd gnashing of teeth: you will be punished with everlasting estruction from the glory of the Lord, and from the glory of his ower. A brother's voice would fain startle you into earnestness. O be ise, be wise in time, and ere another year begins, believe in Jesus, ho is able to save to the uttermost. Consecrate these last hours to onely thought, and if deep repentance be bred in you, it will be well; nd if it lead to a humble faith in Jesus, it will be best of all. O ee to it that this year pass not away, and you an unforgiven spirit. et not the new year's midnight peals sound upon a joyless spirit! Now, ow, NOW believe, and live.

"ESCAPE FOR THY LIFE;

LOOK NOT BEHIND THEE,

NEITHER STAY THOU IN ALL THE PLAIN;

ESCAPE TO THE MOUNTAIN,

LEST THOU BE CONSUMED."
